unnormalised: I'm new to online shopping in India. What are some things I should know about paying online?
normalised: I am new to online shopping in India. What are some things I should know about paying online?

unnormalised: Well, there are a few things to keep in mind, especially when you're just starting out. Firstly, payment gateways. Most Indian e-commerce sites use trusted payment gateways like Razorpay or PayU. You'll often see options to pay with your debit card (like a RuPay card), credit card (Visa, Mastercard, Amex are common), UPI (like PhonePe, Google Pay, or BHIM), or net banking. Sometimes they offer wallets, too, like Paytm, where you might have ₹200 cashback waiting!
normalised: Well, there are a few things to keep in mind, especially when you are just starting out. Firstly, payment gateways. Most Indian e-commerce sites use trusted payment gateways like Razorpay or PayU. You will often see options to pay with your debit card (like a RuPay card), credit card (Visa, Mastercard, Amex are common), U-P-I (like PhonePe, Google Pay, or B-H-I-M), or net banking. Sometimes they offer wallets, too, like Paytm, where you might have rupee two hundred cashback waiting!

unnormalised: Secondly, security. Always check for "https" in the website address and a padlock icon. These indicate that the site uses SSL encryption, protecting your payment details. OTPs (One-Time Passwords) are your friend! Most banks require an OTP for transactions over Rs. 2000 to verify it’s really you making the payment. Be wary of suspicious links or emails asking for your card details. No reputable company will ever ask you to send your CVV (the 3-digit code on the back of your card).
normalised: Secondly, security. Always check for "h-t-t-p-s" in the website address and a padlock icon. These indicate that the site uses S-S-L encryption, protecting your payment details. O-T-P-s (One-Time Passwords) are your friend! Most banks require an O-T-P for transactions over rupees two thousand to verify it is really you making the payment. Be wary of suspicious links or emails asking for your card details. No reputable company will ever ask you to send your C-V-V (the three-digit code on the back of your card).

unnormalised: Thirdly, discounts and offers. Keep an eye out for sales and promotions. Many sites offer discounts for using specific payment methods. For example, you might get 10% off up to ₹500 on a purchase made with an HDFC Bank credit card, or a cashback of ₹100 if you use Amazon Pay Later. Also, check for "No Cost EMI" options, especially for larger purchases like a new phone costing ₹30,000 or more.
normalised: Thirdly, discounts and offers. Keep an eye out for sales and promotions. Many sites offer discounts for using specific payment methods. For example, you might get ten percent off up to rupee five hundred on a purchase made with an H-D-F-C Bank credit card, or a cashback of rupee one hundred if you use Amazon Pay Later. Also, check for "No Cost E-M-I" options, especially for larger purchases like a new phone costing rupees thirty thousand or more.

unnormalised: Finally, refunds and returns. Before buying, read the return policy carefully. See how long you have to return an item (usually 7-30 days), and if there are any charges for returns. Also, keep all payment confirmations and order details as proof of purchase, especially if you face any issues with your order or need to claim a refund of, say, ₹1500. Happy shopping!
